image.altText: A man smiles with his son at an outdoor restaurant

props.synopsis: Jailed Australian man Robert Pether has penned an emotional letter from behind bars in Iraq, saying he feels "abandoned" by the Australian government and worried he will never get home.

title.children: 'Abandoned, sick and worried I won't survive': Australian jailed in Iraq urges country not to forget him

image.altText: A n american flag conceals the face of a bo walking with a gun in a holster on his jeans

props.synopsis: A birthday party in Chicago. A convenience store in New York. A public park in Atlanta. In a single day in the United States, all become the scenes of gun violence.

title.children: 24 hours, seven mass shootings — as an election looms, what does a day of gun violence look like for the United States?

image.altText: A WA Police badge on an officer's shirt shoulder.

props.synopsis: A group of people arrived by boat in Western Australia's northern Kimberley region on Friday, the ABC understands.

title.children: WA Police searching for man thought to have arrived in Australia with group on 'unknown vessel'

image.altText: A man wearing blue hospital gown sits up while nurses in scrubs inspect his scalp

props.synopsis: Young men with heads swaddled in gauze wander through the streets, taking in the sights and sounds of Istanbul. But these aren't regular tourists — they have all come with the same singular mission: to find an antidote to their baldness.

title.children: How Türkiye turned itself into the hair transplant capital of the world — and built a $3b industry

image.altText: A woman with brown wavy hair, wearing a brown shirt with a brown wall behind her smiles and balances her head on one hand

props.synopsis: After being diagnosed with a rare brain tumour in 2017, author and commentator Jamila Rizvi drew on the strength of her support network to stay upright. "Our narratives of illness are, in my view, too focused on stoicism and solitude," she says.

title.children: 'Endurance is fuelled by a deep desire to stay alive': How Jamila Rizvi kept going after her brain tumour diagnosis

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: Time to put your money where your mouth is and trust me, I'm hard to impress.

title.children: Talk a big game when it comes to quizzes? Try this then. Let's play, HARD!

image.altText: A man in a blue suit smiles with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: A former SAS soldier and winner of reality TV show Survivor who has written a book depicting a Chinese invasion of Australia has won the right to represent the Liberal Party in the contest for a federal WA seat.

title.children: 'Tougher than Survivor': New WA Liberal candidate courts controversy with novel about Chinese invasion

image.altText: A man in a green hooded jumper looks at the camera

props.synopsis: Elad Katzir was taken hostage on October 7 by Palestinian gunmen, and had pleaded for his release earlier this year.

title.children: 'Tell my family that I love them': Body of hostage recovered from Gaza by Israeli commandos

image.altText: A child stands next to a flooded road while a mother rides a bike with her baby.

props.synopsis: King tides are not new in Tuvalu, but February's reached areas that had not been flooded before, forcing some Tuvaluans to question how much time they had left in their home country.

title.children: As king tides battered Tuvalu, some of its people weighed up a future in Australia

image.altText: A tug boat pushes a large grey ship in water as a worker in a hard hat watches on from afar

props.synopsis: The naval drills come as tensions continue to rise between China and its neighbours in the disputed territory.

title.children: Australia will join the US, Japan and the Philippines in naval drills in the South China Sea today

image.altText: Pauly Fuemana wearing a black jacket and cravat points to the camera with a red convertible sports car behind him.

props.synopsis: Nearly 30 years after releasing an era-defining song, the Fuenama family are back in the spotlight with the reissue of a forgotten but seminal album.

title.children: How Bizarre: The family behind the 90s global sensation returns to the spotlight

image.altText: Mrs Goddard uses the Hills Hoist in her Kensington yard.

props.synopsis: It started out as a sci-fi genre, but some believe solarpunk holds the key to solving some of humanity's most pressing problems.

title.children: Why has the 100-year-old Hills Hoist emerged as a symbol of 21st century solarpunk design?

image.altText: Donald Trump in front of a background of white stars on blue stripes.

props.synopsis: From ending the war in Ukraine in a day, to encouraging Russia to do "whatever the hell they want" to "delinquent" NATO members, Donald Trump's public proclamations on the foreign policy he'd pursue are alarming allies.

title.children: 'I wouldn't protect you': Trump could win back the White House. Here's how he plans to change the world

image.altText: Larry stands in a doorway and holds the head of a brunette doll up with a serious expression on his face.

props.synopsis: With the finale of Larry David's cult sitcom airing this weekend, here are the six episodes the ABC Entertainment team thinks are pretty, pretttyyy, pretttttyyyyyyy, pretty good.

title.children: Curb Your Enthusiasm is ending. Were these the funniest episodes of all time?

image.altText: Two Geelong players celebrate, with one rubbing the other's head after a goal.

props.synopsis: Geelong get the points over the Western Bulldogs with another dramatic finish at Gather Round after the Blues earn a late win over the Dockers in a crazy final minute with two controversial umpiring calls.

title.children: Stengle stars for Geelong in win over Dogs after umpiring controversy in Blues-Freo finale

image.altText: Dolphins' Herbie Farnworth grimaces as a trainer holds his shoulder during an NRL game.

props.synopsis: The Dolphins handle the Tigers, after Manly takes down Penrith thanks in part to a controversial intercept try. Earlier, Latrell Mitchell was placed on report twice in South Sydney's 34-4 loss to the Warriors.

title.children: Lang Park turns into trauma ward with five players injured in Dolphins' win over Tigers

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the death of seven aid workers, including an Australian, cannot be "brushed aside" by Israel following its investigations into the deadly air strike.

title.children: Penny Wong calls Israeli air strike on aid workers a 'deadly failure'

image.altText: A group of heavily armed police in dark blue uniforms stand outside and scale a spiked wall at night.

props.synopsis: Mexico says it is breaking off diplomatic ties with Ecuador after Ecuadorian police broke into its embassy in Quito to arrest a former vice-president who was seeking political asylum there after being indicted on corruption charges.

title.children: Mexico severs diplomatic ties with Ecuador after police raid Mexican embassy to arrest former VP

image.altText: A spilling Warragamba Dam

props.synopsis: Warragamba Dam has hit capacity and is spilling following more heavy rain in Sydney. It's a reversal of fortunes from a year ago when Sydneysiders were being warned to conserve water.

title.children: Warragamba Dam is spilling after more than 100mm of rain overnight. What happens now?

image.altText: Penrith received 167mm of rain since 9am Friday morning.

props.synopsis: The body of the man, who has not been identified, was found by a member of the public at a reserve in Penrith as police say they aren't able to confirm if the death is flood-related.

title.children: Man's body found near reserve in Sydney's west after massive rainfall pummels the state

image.altText: Metal picnic tables in the middle of a room lined with prison cells.

props.synopsis: The high-security Lockyer Valley Correctional Centre will have no bars on its windows and will focus on prisoner rehabilitation, according to government officials.

title.children: Queensland's largest prison is nearing completion. What will life be like inside?

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a two-storey house with a thriving garden.

props.synopsis: When Averil needed a place to live, her community came together and helped her build a house. To pay for the labour, she made use of a local off-grid economy that trades in "sapphires".

title.children: Averil's idyllic mudbrick home was built in three months and all it cost her was payment in kind

image.altText: A birds eye view of a weather station on a small island

props.synopsis: Willis Island's four locals are paid to keep one the world's most far-flung weather observatories running, and spend six months of the year with no fresh food deliveries or face-to-face contact with the outside world.

title.children: On a good day, life on this remote weather station is like 'holidaying at a beautiful tropical resort'

image.altText: Jean Nassif

props.synopsis: Jean Nassif has left a trail of defect-riddled apartment buildings in his wake, but in an exclusive interview with the ABC, he says he's the number one builder on Earth and that he's been hunted out of Australia by powerful figures.

title.children: A yellow Lambo, gangs and a vendetta: The downfall of the 'number one builder on Earth'

image.altText: a family posing underneath their house

props.synopsis: Zara and Shaun Sarson learned their new Gold Coast home was so badly damaged it had to be demolished. They say new Queensland's laws designed to protect buyers are about five years too late.

title.children: Gold Coast couple forced to demolish termite-riddled home just months after purchase

image.altText: Photo illustration of Steve Jackson, Karen Webb, Bruce Lehrmann and Taylor Auerbach with dark background

props.synopsis: The Federal Court this week played host to allegations of cocaine benders, boozy dinners, $10,000 in sex worker and massage services charged to the Network Seven company card. The unexpected twist has its origins in a much smaller, Sydney political scandal.

title.children: The latest unexpected twist in the Lehrmann defamation trial has origins in a much smaller political scandal

image.altText: A man holding a shiny trading card is smiling, there is a store with stocked shelves behind him

props.synopsis: There has been a resurgence in demand for trading game cards like Pokémon, highlighted by rapper and singer Post Malone's recent purchase of one worth $3.5 million.

title.children: Check your deck, because your old cards could be worth a stack

image.altText: A yellow sign at a park says 'Asbestos: caution'.

props.synopsis: An asbestos removal expert says he is "shocked" asbestos has been found in playground mulch in Victoria, but argues there are "virtually no regulations" around mulch.

title.children: More asbestos detected in Melbourne parks, expert blames cost pressures and lack of regulation

image.altText: Tasmanian political candidates and Parliament House graphic.

props.synopsis: A fisherman, a former laser tag business owner, an ex-television presenter, a one-time school chaplain, a podiatrist and a veteran conservative warrior — these are some of the new (and not so new) faces of Tasmania's incoming parliament.

title.children: The new (and not so new) faces of Tasmania's incoming parliament — and who is out

image.altText: Young boy wearing helmet and football uniform stands on green grassed football oval

props.synopsis: A football team that spent the past two years getting beaten by hundreds of points found itself with a choice to make — give up, or go all in. With a renewed focus on community, families have now returned to the club, so too a sense of hope.

title.children: After losing by 400+ points this club considered folding. What they did next united a community

image.altText: A man in a chef's apron stands in a kitchen with fresh produce surrounding him.

props.synopsis: Indigenous chef Jack Brown is trained in traditional French cuisine, but he's on a mission to get more native Australian ingredients into everyday cooking.

title.children: Classically trained chef says native ingredients key to creating uniquely Australian cuisine

image.altText: Brittany Higgins arrives at court.

props.synopsis: Extracts of the book, tendered to the Federal Court, include descriptions of whisky-fuelled Christmas parties at Parliament House and the behaviour of an infamous group of Liberal cabinet ministers known as the "Big Swinging Dicks".

title.children: Excerpts of Brittany Higgins's unpublished memoir describe a 'Wolf of Wall Street' scene within Canberra's parliament

image.altText: People walking past a brown clad granny flat washed onto side footpath.

props.synopsis: Two people have been taken to hospital in Wollongong after their granny flat was washed away in torrential overnight rainfall.

title.children: 'They had a wild ride': Couple lucky to escape granny flat washed away in downpour
